dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, B, I was reading this piece, and it's really grappling with, uh, neoliberalism. You know, that big idea that's shaped our world for, like, forty years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, B, I was reading this piece, and it's really grappling with, uh, neoliberalism. You know, that big idea that's shaped our world for, like, forty years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But it reinforced the neoliberal economic doctrine that has prevailed for the last 40 years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, A, and it starts out almost sounding like, "Hey, maybe Fukuyama was right all along!" It talks about this resurgence of a rules-based order, and that neoliberalism, um, actually *strengthened* democracy for a while, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, A, and it starts out almost sounding like, Hey, maybe Fukuyama was right all along! It talks about this resurgence of a rules-based order, and that neoliberalism, um, actually strengthened democracy for a while, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Today, as we face a retreat from the rules-based, liberal global order... Neoliberalism has undermined democracy for 40 years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Well, *that's* the irony, isn't it? Because then it immediately pivots to how that "faith in unfettered markets" as the path to shared prosperity... well, it's supposedly thriving these days. But then it implies it really shouldn't be.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, that's the irony, isn't it? Because then it immediately pivots to how that faith in unfettered markets as the path to shared prosperity... well, it's supposedly thriving these days. But then it implies it really shouldn't be.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The credibility of neoliberalisms faith in unfettered markets as the surest road to shared prosperity is on life-support these days.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! It's super sarcastic. Because the reality, according to the author, is that elites promised things like, "Oh, this globalization will empower you, you'll control your destiny!"
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! It's super sarcastic. Because the reality, according to the author, is that elites promised things like, Oh, this globalization will empower you, you'll control your destiny!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The form of globalization prescribed by neoliberalism left individuals and entire societies unable to control an important part of their own destiny...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, like that Wall Street example. You know, if a leading candidate was Wall Street-friendly, boom, investment! Voters had this "choice" between a financial boom or, uh, standing against it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, like that Wall Street example. You know, if a leading candidate was Wall Street-friendly, boom, investment! Voters had this choice between a financial boom or, uh, standing against it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If a leading presidential candidate in an emerging market lost favor with Wall Street, the banks would pull their money out of the country. Voters then faced a stark choice: Give in to Wall Street or face a severe financial crisis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like Wall Street had *less* political power than citizens. Which, I mean, come on. And then they told ordinary folks, "Just pursue these policies – good wages, social protection – and the country will gain competitiveness!"
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like Wall Street had less political power than citizens. Which, I mean, come on. And then they told ordinary folks, Just pursue these policies - good wages, social protection - and the country will gain competitiveness!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Even in rich countries, ordinary citizens were told, You cant pursue the policies you want whether adequate social protection, decent wages, progressive taxation, or a well-regulated financial system because the country will lose competitiveness, jobs will disappear, and you will suffer.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And the *real* kicker is what happened. After 40 years, the numbers are in, and it's not shared prosperity. It's like, growth *increased*, but the fruits went overwhelmingly to a very few, you know, at the bottom.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the real kicker is what happened. After forty years, the numbers are in, and it's not shared prosperity. It's like, growth increased, but the fruits went overwhelmingly to a very few, you know, at the bottom.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Well, after 40 years, the numbers are in: growth has slowed, and the fruits of that growth went overwhelmingly to a very few at the top.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. It wasn't "trickle-down"; it was more like "gush-up." People felt like they'd been, uh, sold a treasure, but it was a total con.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. It wasn't trickle-down; it was more like gush-up. People felt like they'd been, uh, sold a treasure, but it was a total con.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As wages stagnated and the stock market soared, income and wealth flowed up, rather than trickling down... Ordinary citizens felt like they had been sold a bill of goods. They were right to feel conned.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And that feeling of being conned? That led to this huge erosion of trust. Trust in elites, trust in the economic models these policies were based on.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And that feeling of being conned? That led to this huge erosion of trust. Trust in elites, trust in the economic models these policies were based on.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We are now experiencing the political consequences of this grand deception: distrust of the elites, of the economic science on which neoliberalism was based, and of the money-corrupted political system that made it all possible.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And the article even points out how neoliberalism, despite its name, was actually incredibly *illiberal* in practice when it came to dissenting views. It *claimed* intellectual diversity, but really just dismissed anything heterodox.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the article even points out how neoliberalism, despite its name, was actually incredibly illiberal in practice when it came to dissenting views. It claimed intellectual diversity, but really just dismissed anything heterodox.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The reality is that, despite its name, the era of neoliberalism was far from liberal. It imposed an intellectual orthodoxy whose guardians were utterly intolerant of dissent. Economists with heterodox views were treated as heretics to be shunned...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like Karl Popper's open society, but almost turned on its head. When the 2008 crisis hit, they treated it like a "500-year drought," an anomaly, rather than something their models *could* have predicted.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like Karl Popper's open society, but almost turned on its head. When the two thousand eight crisis hit, they treated it like a five hundred-year drought, an anomaly, rather than something their models could have predicted.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When the impossible happened, it was treated as if it were a 500-year flood a freak occurrence that no model could have predicted.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. And even now, after all that, those advocates still cling to this idea of self-regulating markets, ignoring externalities.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. And even now, after all that, those advocates still cling to this idea of self-regulating markets, ignoring externalities.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Even today, advocates of these theories refuse to accept that their belief in self-regulating markets and their dismissal of externalities as either nonexistent or unimportant led to the deregulation that was pivotal in fueling the crisis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild. And the article ends with, you know, this really sharp, sarcastic take on the future. Like, "If 2008 didn't wake us up, maybe the climate crisis will."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild. And the article ends with, you know, this really sharp, sarcastic take on the future. Like, If two thousand eight didn't wake us up, maybe the climate crisis will.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If the 2008 financial crisis failed to make us realize that unfettered markets dont work, the climate crisis certainly should: neoliberalism will literally bring an end to our civilization.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And then the ultimate jab: "The only way forward is to discard the Enlightenment, ignore freedom, and embrace autocracy." Which, obviously, is the complete opposite of what the author believes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then the ultimate jab: The only way forward is to discard the Enlightenment, ignore freedom, and embrace autocracy. Which, obviously, is the complete opposite of what the author believes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The only way forward, the only way to save our planet and our civilization, is a rebirth of history. We must revitalize the Enlightenment and recommit to honoring its values of freedom, respect for knowledge, and democracy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. It's a call to *re-embrace* those Enlightenment values, because ignoring them is what got us into this mess in the first place.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. It's a call to re-embrace those Enlightenment values, because ignoring them is what got us into this mess in the first place.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The only way forward, the only way to save our planet and our civilization, is a rebirth of history. We must revitalize the Enlightenment and recommit to honoring its values of freedom, respect for knowledge, and democracy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty powerful stuff, actually. A real, uh, critical look at the legacy of an economic doctrine.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty powerful stuff, actually. A real, uh, critical look at the legacy of an economic doctrine.
